wiki_catalogs.name: Project Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the Smart Editor Switcher plugin. Explain its purpose as a JetBrains IntelliJ Platform plugin enabling seamless switching between JetBrains IDEs and external editors while preserving context such as cursor position, file path, and project structure. Document the architecture at a high level, emphasizing its modular design with clear separation of concerns between actions, services, settings, and UI components. Highlight the relationship between key components: how UI actions trigger the central EditorSwitcherService, which uses EditorUtils to extract context and execute process switching. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners‚Äîsuch as what problem the plugin solves and who it's for‚Äîand technical details for experienced developers, including integration with IntelliJ's action system, persistent state management, and status bar widget factory pattern. Provide practical examples from the README showing common use cases like switching via keyboard shortcuts or right-click menu. Mention supported editors (VS Code, Cursor, Zed, Kiro, Sublime Text) and core features like auto-detection and cross-platform support. Use terminology consistent with the codebase such as 'EditorSwitcherService', 'SwitchTo*Action', and 'SmartEditorSwitcherConfigurable'.

wiki_catalogs.name: Action Group
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the EditorSwitcherActionGroup UI component. Explain its role in organizing all editor switch actions (VS Code, Cursor, Zed, Kiro, Sublime Text) into a cohesive menu structure accessible from the Tools menu and context menus. Document how it extends IntelliJ's ActionGroup to dynamically build a list of AnAction instances with localized text and descriptions. Include concrete examples from the code showing icon usage (üìò, üéØ, ‚ö°) and separator placement for visual grouping. Describe how each action is instantiated and configured with presentation properties like text and tooltip. Explain integration with IntelliJ's action system and how it supports keyboard shortcuts and mouse interactions. Address usage patterns for developers extending the plugin with new editors. Provide guidance on internationalization considerations and accessibility compliance for menu items. Discuss performance implications of lazy instantiation and memory footprint.

wiki_catalogs.name: Editor Switching
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the editor switching feature of the Smart Editor Switcher plugin. Explain how the EditorSwitcherService orchestrates switching to external editors by validating configured paths and constructing platform-specific command-line arguments. Detail the implementation of each SwitchTo*Action class (VS Code, Cursor, Zed, Kiro, Sublime Text) and how they invoke the central service with the appropriate EditorType enum. Document the differences in CLI syntax across editors‚Äîfor example, VS Code and Cursor using --goto for line navigation, Sublime and Zed accepting file:line:column directly, and Notepad++ requiring -n and -c flags. Include code examples from buildCommand() showing how project context and cursor position are embedded in launch commands. Describe error handling when editor paths are missing or processes fail to start. Address cross-platform considerations in path detection and command execution. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like incorrect paths, missing permissions, or malformed arguments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Switch to VS Code Action
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the SwitchToVSCodeAction class, which implements IntelliJ's AnAction to enable switching from the current IDE to VS Code with full context preservation. Explain how the action extracts editor context (file path, line, column, project) using EditorUtils, checks the configured VS Code executable path via EditorSwitcherService, and triggers the switch via the central switchToEditor method with EditorType.VSCODE. Document the specific command-line invocation pattern used for VS Code (utilizing the -g flag for file:line:column navigation) as handled in the service layer. Include a code example showing the actionPerformed and update method implementations, highlighting error handling when the VS Code path is not configured and user feedback via IntelliJ's Messages API. Explain integration points including registration in plugin.xml, assignment of the default keyboard shortcut (Ctrl+Alt+V), and visibility conditions based on project context. Address troubleshooting scenarios such as VS Code not launching due to incorrect paths or CLI syntax issues, and provide guidance on customizing the launch arguments for different VS Code installations (e.g., insiders build, custom installations).

wiki_catalogs.name: VS Code Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the VS Code integration within the Smart Editor Switcher plugin. Explain how SwitchToVSCodeAction triggers the editor switch by invoking EditorSwitcherService with EditorType.VSCODE. Detail the command construction in buildCommand() where --goto flag is used to navigate to specific file:line:column positions. Document platform-specific VS Code binary paths (e.g., Visual Studio Code.app on macOS, code.cmd on Windows) and how auto-detection works through detectVSCodePath(). Include error handling when VS Code path is not found or process fails to start. Provide code examples showing the interaction between actionPerformed() and switchToEditor(). Address cross-platform considerations in path resolution and CLI argument formatting. Offer troubleshooting tips for common issues like incorrect binary paths, permission errors, or malformed goto syntax.

wiki_catalogs.name: Installation and Setup
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the installation and setup process of the ide_jumper plugin. Thoroughly explain two installation methods: through the JetBrains IDE Plugin interface using 'Install Plugin from Disk' and via manual installation by copying to the plugins directory on macOS, Windows, and Linux. Include concrete examples from INSTALL.md showing exact file paths for both the built plugin ZIP and target IDE plugin directories. Document configuration steps post-installation, including navigating to Tools > Editor Switcher in Settings and configuring executable paths for each supported editor (Kiro, VS Code, Sublime Text), with platform-specific examples. Explain how build.gradle.kts defines compatibility (sinceBuild '232', untilBuild '252.*') and JVM requirements (Java 17), which informs users about IDE version support. Address common issues such as incorrect editor paths, permission errors when launching external processes, and handling spaces in file paths. Provide guidance on verifying successful installation and initial configuration. Make content accessible to beginners while ensuring technical accuracy for advanced users managing multiple IDEs or custom installations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Status Bar Widget
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the EditorSwitcherStatusBarWidget component. Describe its visual appearance as a clickable status bar icon labeled 'ÁºñËæëÂô®ÂàáÊç¢' with a tooltip 'ÁÇπÂáªÂàáÊç¢ÁºñËæëÂô®'. Explain its behavior when clicked‚Äîtriggering a popup menu via JBPopupFactory that displays all available editor options. Document its inheritance from EditorBasedWidget and implementation of MultipleTextValuesPresentation for dynamic text updates. Detail the createPopup() method that constructs the action group popup and handles mouse event consumption. Explain lifecycle methods like install() and dispose() for resource management. Include how it integrates with the project context and retrieves current editor state through IntelliJ APIs. Provide usage examples showing user interaction flow. Address customization options such as text, icon, and tooltip localization. Discuss accessibility features and cross-platform rendering consistency. Highlight the deprecated getPopupStep() method and migration path to modern popup handling.

wiki_catalogs.name: Context Preservation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the context preservation functionality. Explain how EditorUtils extracts critical IDE context‚Äîcurrent file path, project root, and precise cursor line/column numbers‚Äîusing IntelliJ Platform APIs such as Editor, PsiFile, and LogicalPosition. Document how this context is passed to EditorSwitcherService during switchToEditor() calls and embedded into command-line arguments for accurate file and line navigation. Include examples from the codebase showing how cursor position is retrieved via editor.caretModel.primaryCaret.logicalPosition. Address edge cases such as unsaved files, non-text files, or editors that don't support line/column navigation. Discuss performance implications of fast context extraction and minimal UI thread blocking. Provide troubleshooting guidance for issues like incorrect line numbers, missing file paths, or null pointer exceptions during context retrieval.

wiki_catalogs.name: Switch to Cursor Action
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the SwitchToCursorAction class, which enables seamless transition from JetBrains IDEs to the Cursor AI-powered editor while preserving cursor position and file context. Detail the implementation of actionPerformed that retrieves the current editor context via EditorUtils and validates the Cursor executable path stored in EditorSwitcherService. Explain the fallback mechanism that triggers auto-detection if the path is missing, and describe the user feedback flow using showErrorDialog and showInfoMessage. Document how the action invokes the generic switchToEditor method with EditorType.CURSOR, which in turn constructs the appropriate command-line invocation (handled in the service layer). Highlight integration aspects such as menu placement under the Tools > Switch Editor submenu, status bar widget inclusion, and the default keyboard shortcut (Ctrl+Alt+C). Provide practical examples of usage and address common issues like path configuration errors or Cursor launch failures on different operating systems. Include guidance for developers on extending the action with additional Cursor-specific CLI flags for enhanced integration.

wiki_catalogs.name: Cursor Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Cursor editor integration. Explain how SwitchToCursorAction uses EditorSwitcherService to launch Cursor with precise file and cursor position context. Detail the use of --goto flag in buildCommand() similar to VS Code, enabling navigation to file:line:column. Document supported installation paths across operating systems (e.g., Cursor.app on macOS, Cursor.exe on Windows) and auto-detection logic in detectCursorPath(). Describe the fallback mechanism that triggers path detection if cursorPath is empty. Include practical examples from actionPerformed() showing context extraction and service invocation. Address error scenarios such as missing installations or invalid paths. Provide troubleshooting guidance for users encountering launch failures or incorrect file openings.

wiki_catalogs.name: Core Features
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the core features of the Smart Editor Switcher plugin. Focus on the implementation of intelligent editor switching, context preservation (cursor position, file path, project structure), and multiple access methods. Explain how EditorSwitcherService acts as the central coordinator, validating editor paths, constructing command-line arguments, and executing external editor processes via ProcessBuilder. Detail how EditorUtils extracts critical context information such as project root, current file path, and precise cursor line/column numbers using IntelliJ Platform APIs. Document the data flow from user action to process execution, including parameterization of editor launch commands with file and line arguments. Include practical examples from the codebase showing how different editors require different CLI syntax (e.g., VS Code's -g flag for line navigation). Address integration points such as automatic path detection logic and cross-platform path handling. Cover performance considerations like fast context extraction and minimal overhead during switching. Provide troubleshooting guidance for failed launches or incorrect cursor positioning.

wiki_catalogs.name: Widget Factory
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the EditorSwitcherStatusBarWidgetFactory class. Explain its role as the registration and instantiation mechanism for the status bar widget within the IntelliJ Platform. Document how it implements StatusBarWidgetFactory to control widget availability, creation, and disposal. Describe the getId() and getDisplayName() methods used by the IDE to identify and display the widget in settings. Explain the isAvailable() and canBeEnabledOn() methods that determine when the widget should appear. Detail the createWidget() method that instantiates EditorSwitcherStatusBarWidget with the current project context. Include how disposeWidget() ensures proper cleanup. Provide integration examples showing how plugin.xml references this factory to register the widget. Address configuration options for enabling/disabling the widget via IDE settings. Discuss best practices for factory-based UI component registration and memory management in long-running IDE sessions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Access Methods
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the multiple access methods provided by the plugin. Describe how users can trigger editor switching via keyboard shortcuts (e.g., Ctrl+Alt+V for VS Code), the Tools menu, right-click context menu, or the status bar widget. Explain the role of EditorSwitcherActionGroup in organizing menu entries and how individual actions are registered in plugin.xml. Detail the implementation of EditorSwitcherStatusBarWidget and its factory, including UI rendering, popup menu display, and event handling. Include code examples showing how AnAction subclasses integrate with IntelliJ‚Äôs action system. Document how keyboard shortcuts are defined in plugin.xml and mapped to specific actions. Address accessibility considerations and customization options for users to rebind shortcuts or hide the status bar widget. Provide troubleshooting guidance for missing menu items or non-responsive UI elements.

wiki_catalogs.name: Switch to Zed Action
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the SwitchToZedAction class, responsible for switching from JetBrains IDEs to the Zed editor with precise context restoration. Explain the action lifecycle from user trigger to process execution, focusing on context extraction via EditorUtils.getEditorContext and path validation through EditorSwitcherService.zedPath. Document the error handling workflow that prompts users to configure the Zed path if not detected automatically, with appropriate UI feedback using IntelliJ's message dialogs. Describe how the action delegates to EditorSwitcherService.switchToEditor with EditorType.ZED, which handles Zed-specific CLI syntax (e.g., zed <file> --goto <line>:<column>). Cover integration details including registration in plugin.xml, visibility rules implemented in the update method, and default keyboard shortcut (Ctrl+Alt+Z). Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues such as Zed not launching on macOS (path location differences) or Linux (executable name variations), and explain how to customize the launch command for workspace-specific behavior. Include code examples demonstrating the action's structure and interaction with the core service layer.

wiki_catalogs.name: Zed Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Zed editor integration. Explain how SwitchToZedAction initiates switching by calling EditorSwitcherService with EditorType.ZED. Detail the command structure in buildCommand() where Zed accepts direct file:line:column notation without special flags. Document platform-specific binary locations (e.g., Zed.app on macOS, zed.exe on Windows) and auto-detection via detectZedPath(). Highlight the simplicity of Zed's CLI interface compared to other editors. Include code examples showing how project context and file paths are passed directly as arguments. Address error handling when Zed is not installed or path configuration fails. Provide troubleshooting steps for users experiencing launch issues or incorrect cursor positioning.

wiki_catalogs.name: Configuration Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the configuration system of the ide_jumper plugin. Explain how user-defined editor paths are stored and managed using IntelliJ's PersistentStateComponent pattern through SmartEditorSwitcherConfigurable and SmartEditorSwitcherSettingsComponent. Document the UI implementation of the settings panel under Tools > Editor Switcher, including input fields for each editor's executable path and the 'Auto-detect Paths' functionality. Describe the underlying data model for configuration state, including default values, validation rules, and error handling for invalid paths. Include code examples showing how the service layer retrieves configured paths and falls back to auto-detection when paths are missing. Address user experience aspects such as form layout, real-time validation, and persistence across IDE restarts. Provide guidance on best practices for setting correct executable paths on different operating systems and troubleshooting common configuration issues like permission denied errors or incorrect binary locations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Switch to Kiro Action
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the SwitchToKiroAction class, which facilitates switching from JetBrains IDEs to the Kiro editor while maintaining cursor position and file context. Explain the implementation details of the actionPerformed method, including context retrieval via EditorUtils, Kiro path validation through EditorSwitcherService, and the fallback auto-detection mechanism when the path is not configured. Document the user feedback system using IntelliJ's Messages API to display success and error states, with localized error messages in Chinese indicating path configuration requirements. Describe how the action integrates with the unified switching mechanism by calling switchToEditor with EditorType.KIRO, allowing centralized command construction in the service layer. Cover technical aspects such as the action's registration in the IntelliJ action system via plugin.xml, its placement in the Tools menu and action groups, and the default keyboard shortcut (Ctrl+Alt+K). Address platform-specific considerations for Kiro installation paths across Windows, macOS, and Linux, and provide troubleshooting steps for common launch failures. Include guidance for developers on extending the action with additional Kiro CLI options for enhanced functionality.

wiki_catalogs.name: Kiro Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Kiro editor integration. Explain how SwitchToKiroAction interacts with EditorSwitcherService to launch Kiro with full context preservation. Detail the buildCommand() implementation that uses --line and --column flags for precise cursor positioning. Document supported installation paths across platforms and the auto-detection mechanism in detectKiroPath(). Describe how project and file paths are sequentially added to the command array. Include examples from actionPerformed() showing context extraction and error messaging when Kiro path is not configured. Address platform-specific considerations in command execution and provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like missing binaries or incorrect argument formatting.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Interface Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the UI components of the Smart Editor Switcher plugin. Describe the visual appearance and behavior of the status bar widget (EditorSwitcherStatusBarWidget) that provides one-click access to editor switching, including its icon, tooltip, and popup menu. Explain how EditorSwitcherStatusBarWidgetFactory integrates with the IntelliJ Platform to register and instantiate the widget. Document the action group (EditorSwitcherActionGroup) that organizes all switch actions under the Tools menu and right-click context menus. Include usage examples showing how users interact with these components via mouse clicks or keyboard shortcuts. Provide implementation details on how these UI elements retrieve current editor context via EditorUtils and delegate switching logic to EditorSwitcherService. Address customization options such as widget visibility settings and accessibility compliance. Discuss performance considerations like lazy loading of the widget and memory efficiency. Include guidelines for theming support and cross-platform consistency in UI rendering.

wiki_catalogs.name: Switch to Sublime Text Action
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the SwitchToSublimeAction class, which enables context-preserving transitions from JetBrains IDEs to Sublime Text. Explain the action's implementation, focusing on how it extracts the current editing context (file, line, column, project) using EditorUtils and validates the Sublime Text executable path via EditorSwitcherService.sublimePath. Document the error handling flow that triggers path auto-detection and displays configuration guidance when Sublime Text is not found. Describe the integration with the core switching mechanism through EditorSwitcherService.switchToEditor with EditorType.SUBLIME, which handles Sublime Text's specific CLI syntax (subl <file>:<line>:<column>). Cover registration details in plugin.xml, UI integration points (menu, status bar, right-click), and the default keyboard shortcut (Ctrl+Alt+S). Provide practical examples of usage and address common issues such as Sublime Text not launching due to PATH environment differences or installation location variations across platforms. Include guidance for advanced users on customizing the launch command and for developers on maintaining consistency with other editor actions while accommodating Sublime Text's unique CLI requirements.

wiki_catalogs.name: Sublime Text Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Sublime Text integration. Explain how SwitchToSublimeAction utilizes EditorSwitcherService to open files in Sublime Text with exact line and column context. Detail the buildCommand() logic where Sublime accepts file:line:column directly as a single argument. Document platform-specific binary paths (e.g., subl on macOS/Linux, subl.exe on Windows) and auto-detection through detectSublimePath(). Highlight the simplicity of Sublime's CLI interface. Include code examples showing how project context and file paths are passed to the process builder. Address error handling when Sublime is not found or process execution fails. Provide troubleshooting tips for users encountering path resolution issues or malformed command arguments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Editor Switch Actions
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for each editor-specific switch action implemented in the plugin. Thoroughly explain the implementation of SwitchTo*Action classes (VS Code, Cursor, Zed, Kiro, Sublime Text), which extend IntelliJ's AnAction class to provide specific switching functionality. Document how each action extracts context via EditorUtils, validates the target editor's executable path through EditorSwitcherService, and constructs the appropriate command-line invocation with file and line arguments. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing differences in CLI syntax between editors (e.g., VS Code's -g flag vs Sublime Text's :line syntax). Explain the relationship between these actions and IntelliJ's action system, including registration in plugin.xml and assignment of keyboard shortcuts (Ctrl+Alt+V, Ctrl+Alt+K, etc.). Address error handling strategies when editors are not found or fail to launch. Provide guidance on extending the system with new editor actions and maintaining consistency in user experience across all switch options.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technical Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Smart Editor Switcher plugin. Describe the high-level design based on IntelliJ Platform plugin architecture, highlighting key components: service layer (EditorSwitcherService), action system (SwitchTo*Action), settings (SmartEditorSwitcherConfigurable), and UI integration (status bar widget). Document architectural patterns used: Singleton via IntelliJ's application service, Command pattern for actions, Factory pattern for UI components, and Dependency Injection through getInstance(). Explain component interactions and data flows using sequence diagrams in text form, showing how user input propagates through the system. Detail integration points defined in plugin.xml including extensions, application services, and actions. Discuss technical decisions such as using Kotlin for development, targeting Java 17, and supporting IntelliJ builds 232-252.*. Address cross-cutting concerns like configuration persistence, error logging, and cross-platform compatibility. Include infrastructure requirements and deployment topology considerations for plugin distribution via JetBrains Marketplace.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Reference
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the public interfaces exposed by the EditorSwitcherService and EditorUtils classes. For EditorSwitcherService, document all public methods including getInstance(), getEditorPath(), setEditorPath(), and executeSwitch(), specifying parameters, return types, exceptions, and thread safety considerations. For EditorUtils, document context extraction methods like getCurrentFile(), getCursorPosition(), and getProjectRoot(), explaining their dependencies on IntelliJ Platform APIs and return value formats. Include usage examples showing how other components (actions, UI) consume these APIs. Document the service lifecycle and initialization via IntelliJ's service container. Specify version compatibility and stability guarantees for these interfaces. Address common usage patterns and anti-patterns, performance implications of frequent calls, and proper error handling when context is unavailable. Provide migration guidance if internal changes affect public contracts.

wiki_catalogs.name: Development Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create a comprehensive development guide for contributing to the ide_jumper plugin. Explain how to set up the development environment using Gradle and the IntelliJ Gradle plugin configured in build.gradle.kts. Document the build process using './gradlew buildPlugin' and running the plugin in a development IDE instance with './gradlew runIde'. Include testing procedures with './gradlew test' and debugging techniques for IntelliJ Platform plugins. Detail the project structure, explaining the purpose of src/main/kotlin vs bin/main, and resource organization. Cover version management through gradle.properties and release processes using create_github_release.sh. Explain how plugin metadata is defined in plugin.xml and versioned in build.gradle.kts. Provide guidance on implementing new editor integrations, adding features, and maintaining code quality. Include best practices for logging, error handling, and cross-platform development. Address contribution workflows and code review expectations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Troubleshooting
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed troubleshooting content for common issues encountered when using the Smart Editor Switcher plugin. Address problems such as editors not launching (incorrect paths, missing permissions), cursor position not being preserved (CLI argument formatting issues), and auto-detection failures. Provide step-by-step diagnostic procedures: verifying editor paths in settings, checking file system permissions, testing command-line execution manually, and reviewing IDE logs. Include specific solutions from INSTALL.md such as using proper executable paths on different platforms and handling spaces in paths with quotes. Explain how to validate that the plugin is properly installed and loaded via the Plugins settings. Cover issues related to keyboard shortcut conflicts and status bar widget visibility. Provide debugging tips for developers, such as enabling verbose logging and using runIde task to test fixes. Organize issues by category (installation, configuration, runtime) for easy navigation.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: Smart Editor Switcher

## 1. Project Introduction

The **Smart Editor Switcher** is a JetBrains IDE plugin designed to enable seamless transitions between JetBrains IDEs and other mainstream code editors. The plugin's primary purpose is to enhance developer workflow by allowing quick switching between different editing environments while preserving critical context such as cursor position, file path, and project structure.

**Core Goals and Objectives:**
- Enable one-click switching between JetBrains IDE and external editors
- Maintain precise cursor positioning (line and column) during editor transitions
- Preserve project and file context when switching environments
- Support multiple popular editors including VS Code, Cursor, Zed, Kiro, and Sublime Text
- Provide both GUI and keyboard-driven interaction methods

**Target Audience:**
- Developers who use multiple code editors in their daily workflow
- Teams standardizing on JetBrains IDEs but requiring flexibility to use specialized editors
- Power users seeking enhanced productivity through rapid environment switching
- Developers working with AI-focused editors like Cursor and Kiro alongside traditional IDEs

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown

The project follows a modular architecture typical of JetBrains IntelliJ Platform plugins, with clear separation of concerns across different functional areas:

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[User Interface] --> B[Action Handlers]
    B --> C[Service Layer]
    C --> D[Configuration Management]
    C --> E[Editor Utilities]
    D --> F[Persistent State]
    E --> G[Context Extraction]
```

### Design Patterns

The implementation leverages several key design patterns:

- **Singleton Pattern**: `EditorSwitcherService` uses the IntelliJ application service pattern to provide a global instance accessible throughout the IDE
- **State Pattern**: Configuration state is managed through `PersistentStateComponent` with XML serialization
- **Command Pattern**: Each editor switch is implemented as an `AnAction` that encapsulates the switching logic
- **Factory Pattern**: The status bar widget uses a factory pattern for instantiation
- **Dependency Injection**: Components access the central service through `getInstance()` rather than direct instantiation

### System Relationships

```mermaid
graph TD
    UI[User Interface] --> Actions[Action Handlers]
    Settings[Settings UI] --> Service[EditorSwitcherService]
    StatusBar[StatusBar Widget] --> Actions
    ContextMenu[Context Menus] --> Actions
    Actions --> Service
    Service --> Paths[Editor Paths]
    Service --> Process[Process Execution]
```

### Data Flow

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[User Trigger] --> B[Action Event]
    B --> C[Context Extraction]
    C --> D[Service Invocation]
    D --> E[Path Validation]
    E --> F[Command Construction]
    F --> G[Process Execution]
    G --> H[External Editor]
```

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- `SwitchToVSCodeAction.kt`: Entry point for VS Code switching functionality
- `SwitchToCursorAction.kt`: Entry point for Cursor editor switching
- `SwitchToZedAction.kt`: Entry point for Zed editor switching
- `SwitchToKiroAction.kt`: Entry point for Kiro editor switching
- `SwitchToSublimeAction.kt`: Entry point for Sublime Text switching

### Core Modules
- `EditorSwitcherService.kt`: Central service managing editor paths and switching logic
- `SmartEditorSwitcherConfigurable.kt`: Settings UI component for configuration
- `EditorSwitcherStatusBarWidget.kt`: Status bar integration for quick access
- `EditorUtils.kt`: Utility functions for extracting editor context

### Configuration Approach
The plugin uses IntelliJ's standard configuration mechanism with persistent state stored in XML format. Configuration is accessible through the IDE settings under "Tools > Smart Editor Switcher".

Sources:
- [SmartEditorSwitcherConfigurable.kt](src/main/kotlin/io/yanxxcloud/editorswitcher/settings/SmartEditorSwitcherConfigurable.kt)
- [EditorSwitcherService.kt](src/main/kotlin/io/yanxxcloud/editorswitcher/services/EditorSwitcherService.kt)

### External Dependencies
The project relies on the IntelliJ Platform SDK and Kotlin runtime, specified in the build configuration.

Sources:
- [build.gradle.kts](build.gradle.kts)

### Integration Points
The plugin integrates with multiple IntelliJ Platform extension points defined in `plugin.xml`, including:
- Application configurable (settings page)
- Application service (background service)
- Status bar widget factory (UI component)
- Action groups (menu items)
- Keyboard shortcuts

Sources:
- [plugin.xml](src/main/resources/META-INF/plugin.xml)

### Component Relationships

```mermaid
graph LR
    Config[Configuration] --> Service
    UI[User Interface] --> Actions
    Actions --> Service
    Service --> OS[Operating System]
    StatusBar[Status Bar] --> Actions
    ContextMenu[Context Menu] --> Actions
    Service --> AutoDetect[Path Auto-Detection]
```

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview

The Smart Editor Switcher provides comprehensive functionality for switching between JetBrains IDEs and external editors with context preservation:

- **Intelligent Editor Switching**: Seamlessly transition between development environments
- **Cursor Position Preservation**: Maintain exact line and column positioning
- **Project Context Maintenance**: Automatically pass project and file paths
- **Multiple Access Methods**: Keyboard shortcuts, menu items, and status bar widget
- **Automatic Path Detection**: Intelligent discovery of installed editor executables
- **Cross-Platform Support**: Works on Windows, macOS, and Linux systems

### Implementation Highlights

The plugin's key innovation lies in its ability to construct editor-specific command lines that preserve context. Different editors require different command-line argument formats, which the plugin handles through conditional logic in the `buildCommand` method.

Sources:
- [EditorSwitcherService.kt](src/main/kotlin/io/yanxxcloud/editorswitcher/services/EditorSwitcherService.kt)
- [SwitchToVSCodeAction.kt](src/main/kotlin/io/yanxxcloud/editorswitcher/actions/SwitchToVSCodeAction.kt)

### Feature Architecture

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Idle
    Idle --> Switching: User triggers switch
    Switching --> Validate: Check editor path
    Validate --> Detect: Path not configured
    Detect --> Configure: Auto-detect fails
    Configure --> Idle: User configures path
    Validate --> BuildCommand: Path available
    BuildCommand --> Execute: Construct command
    Execute --> Success: Launch editor
    Success --> Idle: Switch complete
    Execute --> Error: Execution failed
    Error --> Notify: Show error message
    Notify --> Idle: Operation complete
```

### Supported Editors and Command Strategies

```mermaid
graph TD
    Editor[Editor Type] --> VSCode
    Editor --> Cursor
    Editor --> Zed
    Editor --> Kiro
    Editor --> Sublime
    VSCode --> Goto[--goto file:line:column]
    Cursor --> Goto[--goto file:line:column]
    Zed --> LineCol[file:line:column]
    Kiro --> LineCol[--line --column]
    Sublime --> LineCol[file:line:column]
```

The architecture demonstrates a well-structured approach to solving the cross-editor switching problem, with particular attention to the nuances of different editor command-line interfaces and cross-platform path considerations.
</blog>
